{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2016}} {{Infobox magazine |title = [[Time (magazine)|Time]] |italic title=no |image_file = Time Magazine Scientology cover.jpg |image_size = 200px |image_caption = Cover page in ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''{{'s}} issue: "The Thriving Cult of Greed and Power" |editor = [[Richard Behar]] |editor_title = Writer |frequency = Published in ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'', May 1991 and ''[[Reader's Digest]]'', October 1991 |category = [[Investigative journalism]] |firstdate = May 6, 1991 |country = United States |website = [http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,972865,00.html Cover Story] }}
"'''The Thriving Cult of Greed and Power'''" is an article, written in 1991 by U.S. [[investigative journalism|investigative journalist]] [[Richard Behar]], which is highly critical of [[Scientology]].
It was first published by ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine on May 6, 1991, as an eight-page cover story,<ref name=time>{{cite news |last=Behar |first=Richard |title=Scientology: The Thriving Cult of Greed and Power |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=May 6, 1991 |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,972865,00.html |accessdate=March 20, 2014|pages=50-57}}</ref><ref name=healy/> and was later published in ''[[Reader's Digest]]'' in October 1991.<ref>{{cite news |last=Behar |first=Richard |last2=Burton|first2=Thomas M. |title= A Dangerous Cult Goes Mainstream |work= [[Reader's Digest]] |date= October 1991 |url= http://www.skeptictank.org/hs/dancult.htm |accessdate= October 25, 2007 |pages=87-92}}</ref> Behar had previously published an article on Scientology in ''[[Forbes]]'' magazine. He stated that he was investigated by [[lawyer|attorneys]] and [[private investigator]]s affiliated with the [[Church of Scientology]] while researching the ''Time'' article, and that investigators contacted his friends and family as well. Behar's article covers topics including [[L. Ron Hubbard]] and the development of Scientology, its [[Scientology controversies|controversies]] over the years and [[Scientology and law|history of litigation]], [[Scientology and psychiatry|conflict with psychiatry]] and the U.S. [[Internal Revenue Service]], the [[Scientology controversies#Noah Lottick|suicide of Noah Lottick]], its [[Scientology status by country|status as a religion]], and its [[Scientology as a business|business dealings]].
After the article's publication, the Church of Scientology mounted a public relations campaign to address issues in the piece. It took out advertisements in ''[[USA Today]]'' for twelve weeks, and Church leader [[David Miscavige]] was interviewed by [[Ted Koppel]] on ''[[Nightline]]'' about what he considered to be an objective bias by the article's author. Miscavige alleged that the article was actually driven by the company [[Eli Lilly and Company|Eli Lilly]], because of Scientology's efforts against the drug [[Prozac]]. The Church of Scientology brought a [[libel]] suit against [[Time Warner]] and Behar, and sued ''Reader's Digest'' in multiple countries in Europe in an attempt to stop the article's publication there. The suit against Time Warner was dismissed in 1996, and the Church of Scientology's petition for a [[writ]] of [[certiorari]] to the [[Supreme Court of the United States]] was denied in 2001.
Behar received awards in honor of his work on the article, including the [[Gerald Loeb Award]], the [[Worth Bingham Prize]], and the [[Conscience-in-Media Award]]. The article has had ramifications in the current treatment of Scientology in the media, with some publications theorizing that journalists are wary of the [[litigation]] that Time Warner went through. The article has been cited by [[Anderson Cooper]] on [[CNN]], in a story on ''[[Panorama (TV series)|Panorama]]''{{'s}} 2007 program "[[Scientology and Me]]" on the [[BBC]], and has been used as a reference for background on the history of Scientology, in books from both the [[cult]] and [[new religious movement]] perspectives.
==Research for the article== [[File:Behar-WorthBinghamAward1.JPG|thumb|U.S. President [[George H. W. Bush]] congratulates [[Richard Behar]] upon his receiving the [[Worth Bingham Prize]] for writing the ''Time'' article (1992).]] Before penning "The Thriving Cult of Greed and Power", Behar had written a 1986 article in ''[[Forbes]]'' magazine, "The Prophet and Profits of Scientology", which reported on the Church of Scientology's business dealings and [[L. Ron Hubbard]]'s financial success.<ref name=behar86>{{cite news |last= Behar |first= Richard |title= The Prophet and Profits of Scientology |work=[[Forbes]] |date= October 27, 1986 |page=314}}</ref> Behar wrote that during research for "The Thriving Cult of Greed and Power", he and a ''Time'' contributing editor were themselves investigated by ten attorneys and six private investigators affiliated with the Church of Scientology.<ref name=bostonherald/><ref name=aim/><ref name=ayella/><ref name=linn>{{cite news |last= Linn |first= Virginia |first2=Alana |last2= Semuels |title= PostScript: When scientologists aren't so clear: Leaders of the Church of Scientology have long had the reputation of being uncooperative with the media. Still, we were surprised at their tenaciousness in trying to control our stories. |work= [[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]] |date= July 31, 2005 |url= http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/05212/546007-270.stm |accessdate= October 25, 2007}}</ref> According to Behar, investigators contacted his friends and previous coworkers to ask them if he had a history of tax or drug problems, and obtained a copy of his personal credit report that had been obtained illegally from a national [[credit bureau]].<ref name=aim/><ref name=linn/><ref name=frantz/><ref>{{cite news |last= Mitchell |first= Susan |title= Scientology: A solution for life or just an evil cult? |work= [[The Sunday Business Post]] |date= July 17, 2005}}</ref> Behar conducted 150 interviews in the course of his research for the article.<ref>{{cite book |last= Morton |first= Andrew |authorlink= Andrew Morton (writer) |title= [[Tom Cruise: An Unauthorized Biography]] |publisher= St. Martin's Press |date= January 15, 2008 |location= New York |isbn= 0-312-35986-1 |page= 155}}</ref>
Behar wrote that the motive of these operatives was to "threaten, harass and discredit him".<ref name=bostonherald/><ref name=linn/> He later learned that the Church of Scientology had assigned its head private investigator to direct the Church's investigation into Behar.<ref name=linn/> ''[[Anderson Cooper 360°]]'' reported that Behar had been contacted by Church of Scientology attorneys numerous times while doing research on the article.<ref name=cooper/> The parents of [[Scientology controversies#Noah Lottick|Noah Lottick]], a Scientologist who had committed suicide, cooperated with ''Time'' and ''Reader's Digest''.<ref name=survey/>
==Synopsis== The full title of the article is "The Thriving Cult of Greed and Power: Ruined lives. Lost fortunes. Federal crimes. Scientology poses as a religion but is really a ruthless global scam — and aiming for the mainstream".<ref name=marr/><ref>{{cite news |last= Staff |title= Time takes a critical look at Scientology |work= [[St. Petersburg Times]] |page= 3B |date= April 30, 1991}}</ref> The article reported on the founding of the Church of Scientology by [[L. Ron Hubbard]] and [[Scientology controversies|controversies]] involving the Church and its affiliated business operations, as well as the suicide of a Scientologist.<ref name=healy/><ref name=survey/> The article related the May 11, 1990, suicide of Dr. [[Edward Lottick]]'s son [[Scientology controversies#Noah Lottick|Noah Antrim Lottick]].<ref name=survey>{{cite journal |last= Lottick |first= Edward |authorlink= Edward Lottick |title= Survey Reveals Physicians' Experience with Cults |journal= [[Cult Observer]] |volume= 10 |issue= 3 |publisher= [[International Cultic Studies Association]] |year= 1993 |url= http://www.csj.org/infoserv_articles/lottick_edward_physician_experience.htm |accessdate= October 25, 2007}}</ref> Lottick was a Russian studies student who had taken a series of Scientology courses; he died after jumping from a hotel tenth floor window.<ref name=suicide>{{cite web|first=Lucy |last=Morgan |title=Scientology got blame for French suicide |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/sptimes/access/26196184.html?dids=26196184:26196184&FMT=FT&FMTS=ABS:FT |work=St. Petersburg Times |date=February 8, 1998 |accessdate=October 17, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071109222226/https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/sptimes/access/26196184.html?dids=26196184%3A26196184&FMT=FT&FMTS=ABS%3AFT |archivedate=November 9, 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The Church of Scientology and Lottick's family have differing positions on the effect Scientology coursework had on him. While none of the parties assigned blame, they expressed misgivings about his death. Initially, his father had thought that Scientology was similar to [[Dale Carnegie]]'s self-improvement techniques; however, after his ordeal, the elder Lottick came to believe that the organization is a "school for psychopaths".<ref name=leisure96>{{cite court |litigants= Church of Scientology International v. Time Warner, Inc., et al. |vol= 92 Civ. 3024 (PKL) |reporter= |opinion= |pinpoint= Judge Leisure, Opinion and Order |court= [[United States District Court for the Southern District of New York]] |date= July 16, 1996 |url=}}</ref> [[Mike Rinder]], the head of the Church of Scientology's [[Office of Special Affairs]] and a Church spokesman, stated "I think Ed Lottick should look in the mirror ... I think Ed Lottick made his son's life intolerable".<ref name=suicide/>
The article outlined a brief history of Scientology, discussing Hubbard's initial background as a [[science fiction]] writer, and cited a California judge who had deemed Hubbard a "pathological liar".<ref name=healy/> The Church of Scientology's [[Scientology and law|litigation history]] was described, in addition to its conflicts with the Internal Revenue Service, with countries regarding whether or not to [[Scientology status by country|accept it as a religion]], and its [[Scientology and psychiatry|position against psychiatry]].<ref name=healy/> Behar wrote of the high costs involved in participation in the Church of Scientology, what he referred to as "front groups and financial scams", and harassment of critics.<ref name=ayella/> He estimated that the Church of Scientology paid US$20 million annually to over one hundred attorneys.<ref name=ayella/> Behar maintained that though the Church of Scientology portrays itself as a religion, it was actually a "hugely profitable global racket" which intimidated members and critics in a [[Mafia]]-like manner.<ref name=aim>{{cite news |last= Kincaid |first= Cliff |first2=Sherrie |last2= Gossett |title= The Press and Scientology |work= [[Accuracy in Media]] |date= June 20, 2005 |url= http://www.aim.org/aim_column/3778_0_3_0_C/ |accessdate= October 25, 2007|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20071222001538/http://www.aim.org/aim_column/3778_0_3_0_C/ |archivedate= December 22, 2007|deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref name=larson/><ref name=salon/>
Cynthia Kisser, then director of the [[Cult Awareness Network]], was quoted: "Scientology is quite likely the most ruthless, the most classically terroristic, the most litigious and the most lucrative cult the country has ever seen. No cult extracts more money from its members".<ref name=healy>{{cite book |last= Healy |first= David |title= Let Them Eat Prozac: The Unhealthy Relationship Between the Pharmaceutical Industry and Depression |publisher= NYU Press |year= 2004 |isbn= 0-8147-3669-6 |page= 58}}</ref><ref name=Signorile>{{cite book |last= Signorile |first= Michelangelo |title= Queer in America: Sex, the Media, and the Closets of Power |publisher= Random House |date= May 4, 1993 |isbn= 978-0-679-41309-7 |page= 275}}</ref>
==Post-publication==
===Church of Scientology's response=== The Church of Scientology responded to the publication of "The Thriving Cult of Greed and Power" by taking out color full-page ads in ''[[USA Today]]'' in May and June 1991, on every weekday for twelve weeks, denouncing the ''Time'' magazine cover article.<ref>{{cite news |last= Staff |title= Scientology's Critical Ads |work= [[The New York Times]] |page=D5 |date= May 31, 1991}}</ref> Two official Church of Scientology responses were titled "Facts vs. Fiction, A Correction of Falsehoods Contained in the May 6, 1991, Issues of ''Time Magazine''", and "The Story That ''Time'' Couldn't Tell".<ref name=miller>{{cite book |last= Miller |first= Timothy |title= America's Alternative Religions |publisher= SUNY Press |year= 1995 |isbn= 0-7914-2398-0 |page= 390}}</ref> Prior to the [[advertising]] campaign, Scientologists distributed 88-page bound booklets which disputed points from Behar's article.<ref name=krueger>{{cite news |last= Krueger |first= Curtis |title= Scientology lambasts Time magazine in ad |work= St. Petersburg Times |page= 1B |date= May 29, 1991}}</ref> The "Fact vs. Fiction" piece was a {{convert|1/4|in|cm|adj=mid|-thick}} booklet, which criticized Behar's article and asserted "Behar's article omits the information on the dozens of community service programs conducted by Scientologists ... which have been acknowledged by community officials".<ref name=cote>{{cite news |last= Cote |first= Neil |title= Church whiffs while trying to whomp Wogs |work= [[The Tampa Tribune]] |page= 1 |date= May 10, 1991}}</ref> One of the advertisements in ''USA Today'' accused ''Time'' of promoting [[Adolf Hitler]] and [[Nazi Germany]], and featured a 1936 issue of ''Time'' which had Hitler's picture on the front cover.<ref name=duckworth>{{cite news |last= Duckworth |first= Erika N. |title= Church of Scientology Attacks Time |work= Greensboro News & Record |page= B3 |date= May 29, 1991}}</ref> The Church of Scientology sent out a news release condemning ''Time''{{'s}} "horrible history of supporting fascism", and said that the article was written because ''Time'' had been pressured by "vested interests".<ref name=krueger/> When asked by the ''[[St. Petersburg Times]]'' whether this was the case, ''Time'' [[Editor in chief|Executive Editor]] Richard Duncan responded "Good Lord, no".<ref name=krueger/> [[Heber Jentzsch]], at the time president of Church of Scientology International, issued a four-page news release which stated "Advertising is the only way the church could be assured of getting its message and its side of the story out to the public without the same vested interests behind the Time article distorting it".<ref name=duckworth/>
After the advertising run critiquing ''Time'' magazine in ''USA Today'' had completed, the Church of Scientology mounted a $3 million public relations campaign about Scientology in ''USA Today'', in June 1991.<ref name=holifield>{{cite news |last= Holifield |first= Rhonda |title= Scientologists answer critics with advertising |work= St. Petersburg Times |date= June 29, 1991 |url= https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/sptimes/access/50640730.html?dids=50640730:50640730&FMT=FT&FMTS=ABS:FT}}</ref> The Church of Scientology placed a 48-page advertising supplement in 1.8 million copies of ''USA Today''.<ref name=holifield/> In a statement to the ''St. Petersburg Times'', Scientology spokesman Richard Haworth explained "What we are trying to do is put the actual facts of [[Dianetics]] and Scientology out there".<ref name=holifield/>
In response to the Church of Scientology's claims of inaccuracies in the article, a lawyer for ''Time'' responded "We've reviewed all of their allegations, and find nothing wrong with the ''Time'' story."<ref name=howard>{{cite news |last= Howard |first= Lucy |author2=Gregory Cerio |title= Scientology Takes On Time |work= [[Newsweek]] |page= 8 |date= June 10, 1991}}</ref> In June 1991, ''[[Newsweek]]'' reported that staffers for ''Time'' said they had received calls from a man claiming to be a [[paralegal]] for ''Time'', who asked them if they had signed a confidentiality form about the article.<ref name=howard/> ''Time'' editors sent staffers a computer memo, warning them about calls related to the article, and staffers told ''Newsweek'' that "sources named in the story say detectives have asked about their talks with Time".<ref name=howard/> A Church of Scientology spokesman called the claims "scurrilous".<ref name=howard/>
On February 14, 1992, Scientology leader [[David Miscavige]] gave [[Ted Koppel]] his first interview on Scientology on the [[ABC News]] program ''[[Nightline]]''.<ref name=abcnews>{{cite news |first1= Ted |last1= Koppel |author1-link= Ted Koppel |first2= Forest |last2= Sawyer |orig-year=February 14, 1992 |title= Scientology Leader Gave ABC First-Ever Interview: David Miscavige, Scientology Leader and Best Man at Tom Cruise's Wedding, Spoke to ABC News' 'Nightline' in 1992 |work= [[Nightline]] |publisher= [[ABC News]] |pages= 1, 3 |date= November 18, 2006 |url= http://abcnews.go.com/Nightline/story?id=2664713&page=1 |accessdate= October 25, 2007}}</ref> The program noted that Scientology has vocal critics and cited Behar's 1991 article. Behar appeared on the program and gave his opinion of why individuals join Scientology, stating that the organization's "ulterior motive" is really to get people to take high-priced [[auditing (Scientology)|audit counseling]].<ref name=abcnews/> Behar stated on the program that he had evidence that members of the Church of Scientology had obtained his personal phone records.<ref name=abcnews/> Later in the program, Koppel questioned Miscavige on the Church of Scientology's response to the ''Time'' magazine article, particularly the $3 million the church spent advertising in ''USA Today''.<ref name=abcnews/> Miscavige explained that the first three weeks of the advertising campaign was meant to correct falsehoods from the ''Time'' article, and the rest of the twelve-week campaign was dedicated to informing the public about Scientology. Koppel asked Miscavige what specifically had upset him about the ''Time'' article, and Miscavige called Behar "a hater".<ref name=abcnews/> Miscavige noted that Behar had written an article on Scientology and the Internal Revenue Service three years before he began work on the ''Time'' piece, and made allegations that Behar had attempted to get two Scientologists kidnapped. When Koppel questioned Miscavige further on this, Miscavige said that individuals had contacted Behar after an earlier article, and Behar had told them to "kidnap Scientologists out".<ref name=abcnews/> Koppel pressed further, noting that this was a serious charge to make, and asked Miscavige if his allegations were accurate, why he had not pressed charges for attempted kidnapping. Miscavige said Koppel was "missing the issue", and said that his real point was that he thought the article was not an objective piece.<ref name=abcnews/>
Miscavige alleged on ''Nightline'' that the article itself was published as a result of a request by [[Eli Lilly and Company]], because of "the damage we had caused to their killer drug Prozac".<ref name=abcnews/> When Koppel asked Miscavige if he had affidavits or evidence to this effect, Miscavige responded "You think they'd admit it?"<ref name=abcnews/> Miscavige stated that "Eli Lilly ordered a reprint of 750,000 copies of ''Time'' magazine before it came out", and that his attempts to investigate the matter with Eli Lilly and associated advertising companies were not successful.<ref name=abcnews/>
===Litigation=== [[File:DOCKET Sup. Ct. 2001 Scientology v. Time Warner certiorari denied.png|thumb|Docket of ''Church of Scientology International v. Time Warner, Inc.'', Petition for Writ of Certiorari to the [[Supreme Court of the United States]] denied.]] The Church brought a libel lawsuit against Time Warner and Behar, seeking damages of $416 million.<ref name=frantz>{{cite news |last= Frantz |first= Douglas |title= An Ultra-Aggressive Use of Investigators and the Courts |work= The New York Times |date= March 9, 1997 |url= https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F01E3D71639F93AA35750C0A961958260 |accessdate= October 25, 2007 |page=31}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last= Kumar |first= J.P. |title= "Fair Game": Leveling the Playing Field in Scientology Litigation |work= The Review of Litigation |volume= 16 |page= 747 |date= Summer 1997}}</ref> The Church alleged false and defamatory statements were made concerning the Church of Scientology International in the ''Time'' article.<ref name=judgeleisure/> More specifically, the Church of Scientology's court statements claimed that Behar had been refining an anti-Scientology focus since his 1986 article in ''Forbes'', which included gathering negative materials about Scientology, and "never accepting anything a Scientologist said and uniformly ignoring anything positive he learned about the Church".<ref name=judgeleisure/> In its initial complaint filing, the Church quoted portions of the Behar article that it alleged were false and defamatory, including the quote from Cynthia Kisser, and Behar's own assertion that Scientology was a "global racket" that intimidated individuals in a "Mafia-like manner".<ref name=judgeleisure/>
[[File:Sci-Behar-Legal.jpg|thumb|left|Bound volumes of documents from [[United States federal court|U.S. federal court]] proceedings, in case ''Church of Scientology International vs. Time Warner Inc. and Richard Behar'']] Noah Lottick's parents submitted [[affidavit]]s in the case, in which they "affirmed the accuracy of each statement in the article"; Edward Lottick "concluded that Scientology therapies were manipulations, and that no Scientology staff members attended the funeral" of their son.<ref name=judgeleisure>{{cite news |last= Leisure, District Judge |title= Church of Scientology v. Time and Richard Behar |via= Court TV, library Web site |pages= 92 Civ. 3024 (PKL), Opinion and Order |publisher= [[United States District Court for the Southern District of New York]] |url= http://www.courttv.com/archive/legaldocs/cyberlaw/scientology1.html |accessdate= October 25, 2007}}</ref> During the litigation, the Church of Scientology attempted to subpoena Behar in a separate ongoing lawsuit with the Internal Revenue Service, and accused a federal magistrate of leaking information to him.<ref name=morgan/> Behar was questioned for over 190 hours during 30 days of depositions with Scientology attorneys in the libel case.<ref name=morgan/> One question was about Behar's life in his parents' home while he was still inside the womb.<ref name=morgan/> ''[[St. Petersburg Times]]'' explained that this question was prompted by [[engram (Dianetics)|Scientology teachings]] that certain problems come from [[prenatal memory|prenatal memories]].<ref name=morgan/> Behar told the ''St. Petersburg Times'' he "felt it was extremely excessive".<ref name=morgan/> In a countersuit, Behar brought up the issues of Church of Scientology private investigators and what he viewed as harassment.<ref name=frantz/><ref name=morgan/> By July 1996, all counts of the libel suit had been dismissed.<ref name=cooper/><ref name=dismissed>{{cite news |last= Staff |title= Judge Dismisses Church of Scientology's $416 Million Lawsuit Against Time Magazine |agency= [[Business Wire]] |date= July 16, 1996}}</ref> In the course of the litigation through 1996, Time Warner had spent $7.3 million in legal defense costs.<ref name=morgan>{{cite news |last= Morgan |first= Lucy |title= Hardball: When Scientology goes to court, it likes to play rough—very rough. |work= St. Petersburg Times |date= January 28, 1998 |url= http://www.sptimes.com/News/32899/TampaBay/Hardball.html |accessdate= October 26, 2007}}</ref> The Church of Scientology also sued several individuals quoted in the ''Time'' article.<ref name=morgan/>
The Church of Scientology sued ''Reader's Digest'' in Switzerland, France, Italy, the Netherlands, and Germany for publishing a condensed version of the ''Time'' story.<ref name=carmody/> The only court to provide a temporary injunction was in [[Lausanne]], Switzerland.<ref>{{cite news |last= Steffens |first= Brian |title= Scientology's Current Target: Reader's Digest |work= The Quill |page= 39 |date= November–December 1991 |url= http://skull.piratehaven.org/~atman/factnet/readdig.txt |accessdate= October 25, 2007}}</ref> In France, Italy, and the Netherlands, the courts either dismissed the Church of Scientology's motions, or set injunction hearings far beyond the date of actual publication.<ref name=carmody/> The company defied the injunction and mailed copies of the article, "Scientology: A Dangerous Cult Goes Mainstream", to their {{nowrap|326,000 Swiss subscribers}}.<ref name=carmody>{{cite news |last= Carmody |first= Deirdre |title= Reader's Digest Defies Court |work= The New York Times |pages= D6 |date= October 2, 1991 |url= https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D0CE3DD1239F931A35753C1A967958260 |accessdate= October 25, 2007}}</ref> Worldwide editor-in-chief of ''Reader's Digest'', [[Kenneth Tomlinson]], told ''The New York Times'' that "a publisher cannot accept a court prohibiting distribution of a serious journalistic piece. ... The court order violates freedom of speech and freedom of the press".<ref name=carmody/> The Church of Scientology subsequently filed a criminal complaint against the ''Digest'' in Lausanne, and [[Mike Rinder]] stated it was in blatant violation of the law.<ref name=carmody/> By defying the Swiss court ban, the ''Reader's Digest'' risked a fine of about $3,400, as well as a potential three months' jail time for the Swiss ''Digest'' editor-in-chief.<ref name=carmody/> A hearing on the injunction was set for November 11, 1991, and the injunction was later lifted by the Swiss court.<ref name=carmody/><ref>{{cite news |last= Staff |title= Swiss Lift Ban on Digest |work=The New York Times |date= November 27, 1991 |url= https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D0CE1DD1438F934A15752C1A967958260&n=Top%2fReference%2fTimes%20Topics%2fOrganizations%2fC%2fChurch%20of%20Scientology |accessdate= October 25, 2007|page=D15}}</ref>
[[File:Sup. Ct. 2001 Scientology v. Time Warner Certiorari.png|thumb|Certiorari record in ''[[United States Reports]]'']] In January 2001, a [[United States federal appeals court]] upheld the dismissal of the Church of Scientology International's case against Time Warner.<ref>{{cite news |last= Staff |title= Time Magazine wins approval of libel suit dismissal |work= [[Atlanta Journal-Constitution]] |date= January 13, 2001 |page=F2}}</ref> In its opinion, the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit]] ruled that Time Warner had not published "The Thriving Cult of Greed and Power" with an actual intent of [[Malice (law)|malice]],<ref name=courtpasses/> a standard that must be met for libel cases involving individuals and public groups.<ref name=courtpasses/> On October 1, 2001, the [[Supreme Court of the United States]] refused to consider reinstating the church's libel case ''Church of Scientology International v. Time Warner Inc.'', 00-1683.<ref name=courtpasses/><ref name=firstamendmentcenter>{{cite web |agency= Associated Press |author= First Amendment Center Online staff |title= High court refuses to hear First Amendment appeals |work= [[First Amendment Center]] |date= October 2, 2001 |url= http://www.firstamendmentcenter.org/news.aspx?id=4583 |accessdate= October 26, 2007 |archiveurl= http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20041215112222/http://www.firstamendmentcenter.org/news.aspx?id=4583 <!--Added by H3llBot--> |archivedate= December 15, 2004}}</ref> Time Warner said it refused to be "intimidated by the church's apparently limitless legal resources."<ref name=courtpasses>{{cite news |last= Staff |title= Court Passes on Scientology Libel Case |agency= Associated Press |date= October 1, 2001}}</ref> In arguments presented to the Supreme Court, the Church of Scientology acknowledged that church officials had "committed improper acts" in the past, but also claimed that: "allegations of past misconduct were false and distorted, the result of the misunderstanding, suspicion and prejudice that typically greet a new religion".<ref name=courtpasses/> Of the rulings for Time Warner, the Church of Scientology complained that they "provide a safe harbor for biased journalism".<ref name=courtpasses/> Behar commented on the Church of Scientology's legal defeat, and said that the lawsuit had a [[chilling effect]]: "It's a tremendous defeat for Scientology ... But of course their doctrine states that the purpose of a suit is to harass, not to win, so from that perspective they hurt us all. They've had a real chilling effect on journalism, both before and after my piece".<ref name=marr>{{cite news |last= Marr |first= David |title= Print and be damned: CULT |work= [[The Age]] |page= 3, Insight section |edition= 1st |date= January 19, 2008}}</ref>
===Awards===
{{multiple image |width = 100 |footer = Awards received by ''Time'' and Richard Behar |image1 = Behar-Loeb Award.jpg |alt1 = Gerald Loeb Award |caption1 = [[Gerald Loeb Award]] |image2 = Behar-WorthBinghamAward3.jpg |alt2 = Worth Bingham Prize |caption2 = [[Worth Bingham Prize]] |image3 = Conscience-in-Media Award.jpg |alt3 = Conscience-in-Media Award |caption3 = [[Conscience-in-Media Award]] }}
As a result of writing the piece, Behar was presented with the 1992 [[Gerald Loeb Award]] for distinguished business and financial journalism, the [[Worth Bingham Prize]],<ref name=ebner>{{cite book |last= Ebner |first= Mark |authorlink= Mark Ebner|author2=[[Andrew Breitbart]] |title= [[Hollywood, Interrupted|Hollywood, Interrupted: Insanity Chic in Babylon – The Case Against Celebrity]] |publisher= John Wiley and Sons |year= 2004 |isbn= 0-471-45051-0 |page= 362}}</ref> the [[Conscience-in-Media Award]] from the [[American Society of Journalists and Authors]],<ref name=dismissed/><ref name=asja>{{cite web |last= Staff |title= ASJA Award Recipients: Outstanding Author Awards |publisher= [[American Society of Journalists and Authors]] |year= 2007 |url= http://www.asja.org/awards/awarhist.php |accessdate= October 26, 2007}}</ref> awarded to "those who have demonstrated singular commitment to the highest principles of journalism at notable personal cost or sacrifice,"<ref name=valk>{{cite news |last= Valk |first= Elizabeth P. |title= From the Publisher |work= Time |date= February 24, 1992 |url= http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,974934,00.html |accessdate= October 25, 2007 |page=16}}</ref> and the [[Cult Awareness Network]]'s Leo J. Ryan Award, in honor of [[Leo Ryan|Congressman Leo J. Ryan]].<ref>{{cite news |last= Behar |first= Richard |title= Richard Behar, acceptance speech, 1992 Leo J. Ryan award |work= (OLD) [[Cult Awareness Network]] conference, Los Angeles |year= 1992 |url= http://www.lermanet.com/scientologyscandals/behar.htm |accessdate= October 25, 2007}}</ref><ref name=henderson>{{cite news |last= Henderson |first= Bob |title= Hubbard from Pinellas to Russia |work= St. Petersburg Times |page= 1 |date= December 28, 1992}}</ref> [[Paulette Cooper]] was also awarded the 1992 Conscience-in-Media Award by the American Society of Journalists and Authors, for her book ''[[The Scandal of Scientology]]''.<ref name=asja/> This was the only time in the history of the American Society of Journalists and Authors that the award was presented to more than one journalist in the same year.<ref name=asja/>
In a February 1992 issue of ''Time'', editor Elizabeth Valk congratulated Behar on his Conscience-in-Media Award, stating "Needless to say, we are delighted and proud".<ref name=valk/> Valk noted that the honor had only been awarded seven times in the previous seventeen years of its existence.<ref name=valk/> Managing editor Henry Muller also congratulated Behar in an April 1992 issue of ''Time''.<ref name=muller>{{cite news |last= Muller |first= Henry |title= From the Managing Editor |work= Time |date= April 13, 1992 |url= http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,975279,00.html |accessdate= October 25, 2007 |page=20}}</ref>
==Analysis== Several authors have commented on the article and used it as a reference for background on Scientology.<ref name=healy/><ref name=cooper/> Not all analysis of the article has been positive. [[David Healy (psychiatrist)|David Healy]]'s book criticizing the [[pharmaceutical industry]], ''Let Them Eat Prozac'', was critical: "The ''Time'' article was way over the top. Even [[Saddam Hussein]] was portrayed less badly." Healy addressed the article's claim that lawsuits were one of the Church's key tactics against enemies. He noted that the [[Citizens Commission on Human Rights]] (CCHR), a Church of Scientology affiliated group discussed in the article, had filed a petition with the [[Food and Drug Administration]] inquiring what it was going to do about [[Prozac]]. Healy dismissed the notion that CCHR engaged in "orchestrated campaigns", writing that very few of the 50 lawsuits filed against Prozac were related to the Church of Scientology.<ref name=healy/> [[Mark Silk]] criticized Behar's article in his book ''Unsecular Media: Making News of Religion in America''.<ref name=silk>{{cite book |last= Silk |first= Mark |title= Unsecular Media: Making News of Religion in America |publisher= University of Illinois Press |year= 1995 |pages= 96–97 |isbn= 0-252-06742-8}}</ref> Silk classified the work among what he referred to as the "false-prophecy [[Literary topos|topos]]", and characterized Behar's account of Noah Lottick's suicide as an "[[atrocity tale]]".<ref name=silk/>
''Insane Therapy'' noted that Scientology "achieved more notoriety ... with the publication of the journalist Richard Behar's highly critical article".<ref name=ayella/> ''[[Larson's Book of World Religions and Alternative Spirituality]]'' described the cover design of the article as it appeared in ''Time'', writing that it "shouted" the headline from the magazine cover.<ref name=larson/> In a 2005 piece, ''[[Salon.com]]'' magazine noted that for those interested in the Church of Scientology, the ''Time'' article still remains a "milestone in news coverage", and that those who back the Church believe it was "an outrageously biased account".<ref name=salon>{{cite news |last= Strupp |first= Joe |title= The press vs. Scientology: After years of conflict, the church and the media seem to have reached a truce. Is it because Scientology has become less confrontational—or because the press is scared? |website= [[Salon (website)|Salon]] |pages= 1–3 |date= June 30, 2005 |url= http://dir.salon.com/story/news/feature/2005/06/30/scientology/index.html |accessdate= October 25, 2007 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070107223456/http://dir.salon.com/story/news/feature/2005/06/30/scientology/index.html |archivedate= January 7, 2007 |df= mdy-all }}</ref>
==Legacy== The Church of Scientology's use of private investigators was cited in a 1998 article in the ''[[Boston Herald]]'', and compared to Behar's experiences when researching "The Thriving Cult of Greed and Power".<ref name=bostonherald/> After the paper ran a five-part series of critical articles in 1998, Church of Scientology President [[Heber Jentzsch]] confirmed that a private investigative firm was hired to look into the personal life of Joseph Mallia, the reporter who wrote the articles.<ref name=bostonherald/> In a later piece titled "Church of Scientology probes Herald reporter—Investigation follows pattern of harassment" this investigation was likened to Behar's assertions of harassment, as well as other reporters' experiences from 1974, 1988, and 1997.<ref name=bostonherald>{{cite news |last= MacLaughlin |first= Jim |first2=Andrew |last2= Gully |title= Church of Scientology probes Herald reporter: Investigation follows pattern of harassment |work= [[Boston Herald]] |date= March 19, 1998 |page=004}}</ref>
Because of the history of conflict between ''Reader's Digest'' and Scientology, the writer of a 2005 cover story on [[Tom Cruise]] agreed to certain demands, including giving Scientology issues equal play in the writer's profile of Cruise, submitting questions for Cruise to Church of Scientology handlers, and sending the writer of the article to a one-day Church immersion course.<ref>{{cite news |last= Staff |title= Reader's Digest on Cruise Control |work= [[Radar Online]] |date= June 8, 2005 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20050611003009/http://www.radaronline.com/fresh-intelligence/2005/06/08/index.php |url= http://www.radaronline.com/fresh-intelligence/2005/06/08/index.php |archive-date= June 11, 2005}}</ref> Also in 2005, an article in ''Salon'' questioned whether the tactics of the Church's litigation and private investigations of Time Warner and other media sources had succeeded in decreasing the amount of investigative journalism pieces on Scientology in the press.<ref name=salon/> A 2005 article in ''[[The Sunday Times]]'' cited the article, and came to the determination that the Church of Scientology's lawsuit against Time Warner "served to warn off other potential investigations", and that "The chill evidently lingers still".<ref name=sundaytimes>{{cite news |last= Rowan |first= David |title= Tom, three questions for you: The film star should be facing robust media interrogation about Scientology, but there is craven silence |work= [[The Sunday Times]] |date= July 12, 2005 |url= http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/columnists/guest_contributors/article542911.ece |accessdate= October 25, 2007}}</ref>
"The Thriving Cult of Greed and Power" continues to be used today by journalists in the media, as a reference for historical information on the Church of Scientology.<ref>{{cite news |last= O'Keefe |first= Mark |title= Church of Scientology Is No Stranger to Criticism |work= [[The Oregonian]] |page= A16 |date= September 26, 1996}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title= Science Fiction? – Factual results needed from reading program |work= [[The Commercial Appeal]] |page= A6 |date= September 5, 1995}}</ref><ref name=minneapolis>{{cite news |last= Estrada |first= Heron Marquez |title= Scientology: Fact or fiction? The Church of Scientology, after years out of the spotlight, is under renewed scrutiny—and the object of greater curiosity in the Twin Cities—following Tom Cruise's public psychoanalysis spat with Brooke Shields |work= [[Star Tribune]] ||location= Minneapolis |page= 12E |date= October 22, 2005}}</ref><ref name=friedman>{{cite news |last= Friedman |first= Roger |title= Katie Holmes' Missing Days |publisher= [[Fox News]] |date= June 21, 2005 |url= http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,160192,00.html |accessdate= October 25, 2007 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20071023053312/http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,160192,00.html# |archive-date= October 23, 2007 |dead-url= yes |df= mdy-all }}</ref> In April 2007, [[CNN]] anchor [[Anderson Cooper]] interviewed former [[Office of Special Affairs]] director [[Mike Rinder]],<ref name=johncook>{{cite news |last= Cook |first= John |title= Scientology – Cult Friction: After an embarrassing string of high-profile defection and leaked videos, Scientology is under attack from a faceless cabal of online activists. Has America's most controversial religion finally met its match? |work= Radar Online |date= March 17, 2008 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20080324233413/http://www.radarmagazine.com/from-the-magazine/2008/03/scientology_anonymous_protests_tom_cruise_01.php |url= http://radarmagazine.com/from-the-magazine/2008/03/scientology_anonymous_protests_tom_cruise_01.php |archive-date= March 24, 2008}}</ref> in a live piece on ''[[Anderson Cooper 360°]]'' titled "Inside Scientology".<ref name=cooper>{{cite news |last= [[CNN]] staff |first2= Anderson |last2= Cooper |author2-link= Anderson Cooper |title= Massive Manhunt Continues For Three Missing U.S. Soldiers in Iraq; Inside Scientology |work= [[Anderson Cooper 360°]] |date= April 14, 2007 |url= http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0705/14/acd.01.html |accessdate= October 25, 2007}}</ref> The CNN story was prompted by the May 2007 airing of a [[BBC]] ''[[Panorama (TV series)|Panorama]]'' [[investigative journalism|investigative]] program, "[[Scientology and Me]]". In the interview, Anderson Cooper quoted directly from "The Thriving Cult of Greed and Power" article, when asking Rinder about the history of [[Operation Snow White]], and if those tactics were currently used by the Church.<ref name=cooper/> Rinder answered by stating that the individuals involved with Operation Snow White were no longer involved in Church of Scientology activities, and that the incident was "ancient history". Cooper then again referenced the ''Time'' magazine article noting that Behar asserted that he was illegally investigated by Scientology contacts during research for his article.<ref name=cooper/> Cooper questioned Rinder on the dismissed lawsuit against [[Time Warner]], and Rinder acknowledged that all of the Church of Scientology's appeals against Time Warner were eventually rejected.<ref name=cooper/>
The article has been cited as a reference used for background on Scientology in books which take a critical look at cults such as ''[[Larson's Book of World Religions and Alternative Spirituality]]'' and ''Insane Therapy: Portrait of a Psychotherapy Cult'',<ref name=ayella>{{cite book |last= Ayella |first= Marybeth F. |title= Insane Therapy: Portrait of a Psychotherapy Cult |publisher= Temple University Press |year= 1998 |isbn= 1-56639-601-8 |page= 9}}</ref><ref name=larson>{{cite book |last= Larson |first= Bob |authorlink= Bob Larson |title= [[Larson's Book of World Religions and Alternative Spirituality]] |publisher= Tyndale House Publishers |year= 2004 |isbn= 0-8423-6417-X |page= 431}}</ref> those that analyze [[new religious movement]]s including ''Understanding New Religious Movements'' and ''The Oxford Handbook of New Religious Movements'',<ref name=saliba>{{cite book |last= Saliba |first= John A. |author-link= John A. Saliba |first2= J. Gordon (foreword) |last2= Melton |author2-link= J. Gordon Melton |title= Understanding New Religious Movements |publisher= Rowman Altamira |year= 2003 |isbn= 0-7591-0356-9 |page= 200}}</ref><ref name=lewis>{{cite book |last= Lewis |first= James R. |authorlink= James R. Lewis (scholar) |title= The Oxford Handbook of New Religious Movements |publisher= Oxford University Press |year= 2004 |isbn= 0-19-514986-6 |page= 202}}</ref> and in a work that includes researchers from both schools of thought, ''[[Misunderstanding Cults|Misunderstanding Cults: Searching for Objectivity in a Controversial Field]]''.<ref name=zablocki>{{cite book |last= Zablocki |first= Benjamin David |authorlink= Benjamin Zablocki |first2=Thomas |last2= Robbins |title= [[Misunderstanding Cults|Misunderstanding Cults: Searching for Objectivity in a Controversial Field]] |publisher= University of Toronto Press |year= 2001 |isbn= 0-8020-8188-6 |page= 65}}</ref>

{{Infobox U.S. legislation | name = Truth in Lending Act | fullname = An Act to safeguard the consumer in connection with the utilization of credit by requiring full disclosure of the terms and conditions of finance charges in credit transactions or in offers to extend credit; by restricting the garnishment of wages; and by creating the National Commission on Consumer Finance to study and make recommendations on the need for further regulation of the consumer finance industry; and for other purposes. | acronym = TILA, CCPA | nickname = Consumer Credit Protection Act | enacted by = 90th | effective date = May 29, 1968 | public law url = http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/STATUTE-82/pdf/STATUTE-82-Pg146.pdf | cite public law = 90-321 | cite statutes at large = {{usstat|82|146}} | acts amended = | acts repealed = | title amended = [[Title 15 of the United States Code|15 U.S.C.: Commerce and Trade]] | sections created = {{Usc-title-chap|15|41}} § 1601 | sections amended = | leghisturl= | introducedin= Senate | introducedbill= {{USBill|90|S.|5}} | introducedby= [[William Proxmire]] ([[Democratic Party (United States)|D]]–[[Wisconsin|WI]]) | introduceddate= January 11, 1967 | committees= [[United States Senate Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs|Senate Banking Committee]], [[United States House Committee on Financial Services|House Committee on Banking and Currency]] | passedbody1= Senate | passeddate1= July 11, 1967 | passedvote1= [http://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/90-1967/s126 92–0] | passedbody2= House | passeddate2= February 1, 1968 | passedvote2= [http://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/90-1968/h250 383–4], in lieu of {{USBill|90|H.R.|11601}} | conferencedate= May 22, 1968 | agreedbody3= House | agreeddate3= May 22, 1968 | agreedvote3= agreed | agreedbody4= Senate | agreeddate4= May 22, 1968 | agreedvote4= agreed | signedpresident = [[Lyndon B. Johnson]] | signeddate = May 29, 1968 | amendments = [[Credit CARD Act of 2009]]
[[Dodd–Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act]]
[[Economic Growth, Regulatory Relief and Consumer Protection Act]] | SCOTUS cases = }} The '''Truth in Lending Act''' '''(TILA)''' of 1968 is a [[United States federal law]] designed to promote the informed use of [[consumer credit]], by requiring disclosures about its terms and cost to standardize the manner in which costs associated with borrowing are calculated and disclosed.{{cite book |title=Intro to Business|last1=Dlabay|first1=Les R. |last2=Burrow |first2=James L. |last3=Brad |first3=Brad |year=2009|publisher=South-Western [[Cengage Learning]]|location=[[Mason, Ohio]]|isbn=978-0-538-44561-0 |page=469}} TILA also gives consumers the right to cancel certain credit transactions that involve a [[lien]] on a consumer's principal dwelling, regulates certain [[credit card]] practices, and provides a means for fair and timely resolution of credit billing disputes. With the exception of certain high-cost [[mortgage loan]]s, TILA does not regulate the charges that may be imposed for consumer credit. Rather, it requires uniform or standardized disclosure of costs and charges so that consumers can shop. It also imposes limitations on home equity plans that are subject to the requirements of {{USCFR|12|1026|40}} and certain "higher-priced" mortgage loans (HPMLs) that are subject to the requirements of {{USCFR|12|1026|35}}. The regulation prohibits certain acts or practices in connection with credit secured by a consumer's principal [[dwelling]]. ==History== The Truth in Lending Act was originally Title I of the [[Consumer Credit Protection Act]], {{USStatute|90|321|82|146|1968|05|29}}. The regulations implementing the statute, which are known as "Regulation Z", are codified at {{USCFR|12|226}}. Most of the specific requirements imposed by TILA are found in Regulation Z, so a reference to the requirements of TILA usually refers to the requirements contained in Regulation Z, as well as the statute itself.{{cite web |url=http://www.federalreserve.gov/bankinforeg/reglisting.htm#Z |title=Federal Reserve System Banking Information and Regulation |date=July 30, 2008|work=Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System |publisher=FRB}} From TILA's inception, the authority to implement the statute by issuing regulations was given to the Federal Reserve Board (FRB). However, effective July 21, 2011, TILA's general rule making authority was transferred to the [[Consumer Financial Protection Bureau]] (CFPB), whose authority was established pursuant to provisions enacted by the passage of the [[Dodd–Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act]] in July 2010. Any forthcoming regulations implementing the statute, which are also formally referred to as Regulation Z, will be codified at {{USCFR|12|1026}} and attempt to mirror the FRB's Regulation Z whenever feasible.{{cite press release|url=http://www.consumerfinance.gov/newsroom/consumer-financial-protection-bureau-lays-out-implementation-plan-for-new-mortgage-rules/ |title=CFPB Lays Out Implementation Plan for New Mortgage Rules |date=February 13, 2013|work=Consumer Financial Protection Bureau |publisher=CFPB}} The Federal Reserve will retain some limited rule making authority under TILA for loans made by certain motor vehicle dealers, and for certain other provisions. The TILA introduced the Annual Percentage Rate (APR) calculation mandated for all consumer lenders. Certain misleading interest rate calculations used previously, mainly on auto loans, were barred. For more than a decade, consumer loans were reported by APR in an economically meaningful way. Then in the 1980s the auto manufacturers began to exploit a loophole in TILA and its administration. Neither the Act nor its administrators adequately differentiated between "amount financed" and "finance charges," two terms that appear on the TILA required disclosure statements. By "bundling" the price of the car and its financing charges (which come from the auto maker's captive finance company), auto makers were able to shift money between the two categories, even to eliminating the financing charge entirely. Thus "zero percent APR" financing was born. Typical offers from auto companies are "Zero Percent APR financing available or $1,000 rebate." The consumer who elects "zero percent" financing gives up a $1,000 rebate (reduction in car price). Effectively, he or she pays $1,000 to get the "interest free" loan. Since only auto makers can do this type of bundling, banks, credit unions and other competitors are left at a disadvantage. They must disclose true APR rates while the auto makers can claim no interest costs. In the process, the typical consumer is left with a complex finance problem. "Zero percent" financing can cost a lot less, or a lot more than conventional financing with a non-auto maker institution. ==Organization== The regulation is divided into subparts. Subpart B relates to open-end credit lines ([[revolving credit]] accounts), which includes credit card accounts and home-equity lines of credit (HELOCs). Subpart C relates to closed-end credit, such as home-purchase loans and motor vehicle loans with a fixed loan term. It contains rules on disclosures, treatment of credit balances, [[annual percentage rate]] calculations, right of rescission,non requirements, and advertising. Subpart D contains rules on oral disclosures, [[Spanish language]] disclosure in [[Puerto Rico]], record retention, effect on state laws, state exemptions (which only apply to states that had Truth in Lending-type laws prior to the Federal Act), and rate limitations. Subpart E contains special rules for mortgage transactions.{{cite web|url=http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/granule/CFR-2013-title12-vol8/CFR-2013-title12-vol8-part1026-subpartE/content-detail.html |title=12 C.F.R. 1026, Subpart E, §§ 31–45 (2013 Edition)|date=January 1, 2013|work=Code of Federal Regulations|publisher=GPO}} * § 1026.32 frames the requirements for certain closed-end home mortgages. * § 1026.33 are requirements for [[reverse mortgage]] mortgages, including the total annual loan cost rate and transaction disclosures.{{cn|date=November 2013}} * § 1026.34 prohibits acts or practices in connection with "high-cost" mortgages. * § 1026.35 prohibits acts or practices in connection with "higher-priced" mortgage loans (HPMLs). * § 1026.36 prohibits acts or practices in connection with credit secured by a dwelling. * § 1026.39 deals with mortgage transfer disclosure guidelines. * § 1026.40 sets the requirements for home equity plans. * § 1026.42 aims to promote valuation independence. Several appendices contain information such as the procedures for determinations about state laws, state exemptions and issuance of staff interpretations, special rules for certain kinds of credit plans, a list of enforcement agencies, model disclosures which if used properly will ensure compliance with the Act, and the rules for computing [[annual percentage rate]]s in closed-end credit transactions and total annual loan cost rates for [[reverse mortgage]] transactions. ==Right of rescission== {{unsourced section|date=May 2018}} For certain transactions secured by a borrower's principle dwelling, TILA requires that the borrower be granted three business days following loan consummation to rescind the transaction. The right of rescission allows borrowers time to reexamine the credit agreement and cost disclosures, as well as to reconsider whether they want to place their homes at risk by offering it as security for the credit. Each borrower and any person who has a vested interest in the property may exercise the right to rescind until midnight of the third business day following consummation, or delivery of all material disclosures, whichever occurs last. If the required rescission notice or material TILA disclosures are inaccurate or not delivered, the borrowers right to rescind may be extended from three days after consummation to up to three years. When a borrower rescinds, the security interest becomes void and the borrower is not liable for any amount, including finance charges. The bank must return any money or property given to anyone in connection with the transaction within 20 calendar days and remove any record of security interest that the bank may have taken for the new loan. Until the rescission period has ended, the bank may not 1) disperse funds other than to a valid escrow account, 2) perform any services, or 3) deliver any materials. The right of rescission does not apply to loans that are obtained for the purpose of purchasing a home, nor does it apply to a refinance or consolidation of a home loan with the same creditor unless the amount refinanced or consolidated exceeds the unpaid balance on the existing debt. ==Exemptions== TILA requirements do not apply to the following types of loans or credit: * Credit extended primarily for business, agricultural or commercial purposes; * Credit extended to an entity (not a person, with an exception for certain trusts for tax or estate planning), including government agencies or instrumentalities. * Credit in excess of an annually adjusted threshold, not secured by real estate or personal property, used or expected to be used as a principal dwelling; ==See also== * [[Truth in Savings Act]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{More footnotes|date=April 2009}} ==Further reading== * United States Code (2004). [http://uscode.house.gov/uscode-cgi/fastweb.exe?getdoc+uscview+t13t16+1813+1++%28%29%20%20AND%20%28%2815%29%20ADJ%20USC%29%3ACITE%20AND%20%28USC%20w%2F10%20%281601%29%29%3ACITE%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20#hit0000 15 USC 1601 et seq.]. * [https://fdic.gov/regulations/laws/rules/6500-3200.html#fdic65001026.1 Read the Regulation] * [https://www.occ.gov/publications/publications-by-type/comptrollers-handbook/truth-in-lending-act/pub-ch-tila.pdf Truth in Lending Handbook], Office of Comptroller of the Currency, Administrator of National Banks, December 2006. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110830052956/http://www.llsdc.org/TILA-LH/ Truth in Lending Act Legislative History] Law Librarian's Society of D.C. {{Bank regulation in the United States}} [[Category:United States federal banking legislation]] [[Category:Consumer protection law]] [[Category:Consumer protection legislation]] [[Category:1968 in law]] [[Category:1968 in the United States]] [[Category:Consumer protection in the United States]]

page.title: USA/USSR Joint Statement on Uniform Acceptance of Rules of International Law Governing Innocent Passage

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=September 2007}}
The [[Joint Statement]] by the [[United States|USA]] and the [[Soviet Union|USSR]] (the [[superpower]]s of the time) was made to counteract state activity to restrict the passage of ships carrying potentially hazardous materials through states' [[territorial sea]], culminating mainly from the [[Basel Convention]] 1989. It was made on 23 September 1989.
It made it clear that the text of the 1982 [[United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea]] (UNCLOS) reflected [[customary international law]], and every ship, regardless of cargo, does not need permission to enter another state's [[territorial sea]] so long as it adheres to the definition of [[innocent passage]] in Article 19 of [[UNCLOS]].
{{DEFAULTSORT:USA USSR Joint Statement on Uniform Acceptance of Rules of International Law Governing Innocent Passage}} [[Category:Law of the sea]] [[Category:Soviet Union–United States relations]] [[Category:1989 in the Soviet Union]] [[Category:1989 in the United States]] [[Category:1989 in international relations]] [[Category:1989 in law]]
